thread.title: Lewiston mayoral candidate's ethnicity attacked in controversial signs
thread.title_full: Lewiston mayoral candidate's ethnicity attacked in controversial signs

title: Lewiston mayoral candidate's ethnicity attacked in controversial signs
text:
Lewiston mayoral candidate's ethnicity attacked in controversial signs Incumbent MacDonald says he is not behind signs attacking rival UPDATED 11:43 AM EDT Oct 19, 2015 
A sign posted on Main Street in Lewiston Courtesy: Mike Tipping 
A sign posted on Main Street in Lewiston Courtesy: Mike Tipping 
Signs attacking Lewiston mayoral candidate Ben Chin’s ethnicity were placed on two downtown buildings over the weekend. Related 
The signs read, “Don’t vote for Ho Chi Chin; vote for more jobs not welfare.” Chin is of Asian decent. 
The signs were discovered hanging from buildings on Main Street and Pine Street. 
“The future of Lewiston is too important to be sidetracked by filth like this,” said Chin in an email. “It will only make me fight harder to bring people together to revitalize Lewiston and improve our city’s reputation.” 
Mayor Bob MacDonald told WMTW News 8 in a phone interview that he has nothing to do with the signs. MacDonald is running for reelection. 
MacDonald said he overheard talk of the signs in a coffee shop and told the person, “Please don’t do it. It will only come back on me,” he said. 
It is unclear who is responsible for posting the signs.
